trans-unit.source: "++" and "--" work as in C. That is, if placed before a variable, they increment or decrement the variable by one before returning the value, and if placed after, increment or decrement after returning the value.

trans-unit.source: "LATIN CAPITAL LETTER E WITH ACUTE" is called a "pre-composed" character, and its equivalence with the "E" and the "COMBINING ACCENT" sequence is called canonical equivalence. All pre-composed characters are said to have a decomposition (into the equivalent sequence), and the decomposition type is also called canonical. A string may be comprised as much as possible of precomposed characters, or it may be comprised of entirely decomposed characters. Unicode calls these respectively, "Normalization Form Composed" (NFC) and "Normalization Form Decomposed". The Unicode::Normalize module contains functions that convert between the two. A string may also have both composed characters and decomposed characters; this module can be used to make it all one or the other.

"LATIN CAPITAL LETTER E WITH ACUTE" is called a "pre-composed" character, and its equivalence with the "E" and the "COMBINING ACCENT" sequence is called canonical equivalence. All pre-composed characters are said to have a decomposition (into the equivalent sequence), and the decomposition type is also called canonical. A string may be comprised as much as possible of precomposed characters, or it may be comprised of entirely decomposed characters. Unicode calls these respectively, "Normalization Form Composed" (NFC) and "Normalization Form Decomposed". The Unicode::Normalize module contains functions that convert between the two. A string may also have both composed characters and decomposed characters; this module can be used to make it all one or the other.
trans-unit.target: "LATIN CAPITAL LETTER E WITH ACUTE" se denomina carácter "precompuesto", y su equivalencia con la secuencia "E" y "ACENTO COMBINADO" se denomina equivalencia canónica. Se dice que todos los caracteres precompuestos tienen una descomposición (en la secuencia equivalente), y el tipo de descomposición también se llama canónico. Una cadena puede estar compuesta tanto como sea posible por caracteres precompuestos, o puede estar compuesta por caracteres completamente descompuestos. Unicode los llama, respectivamente, "Forma de normalización compuesta" (NFC) y "Forma de normalización descompuesta". El módulo Unicode::Normalize contiene funciones que convierten entre los dos. Una cadena también puede tener tanto caracteres compuestos como caracteres descompuestos;este módulo se puede utilizar para hacer todo uno o el otro.

"lt" , "le" , "ge" , "gt" and "cmp" use the collation (sort) order specified by the current LC_COLLATE locale if a use locale form that includes collation is in effect. See perllocale. Do not mix these with Unicode, only use them with legacy 8-bit locale encodings. The standard Unicode::Collate and Unicode::Collate::Locale modules offer much more powerful solutions to collation issues.
trans-unit.target: "lt" , "le" , "ge" , "gt" y "cmp" usan el orden de clasificación (clasificación) especificado por la LC_COLLATE regional LC_COLLATE actual si está en vigor un formulario de use locale uso que incluye la clasificación. Ver perllocale . No los mezcle con Unicode, solo utilícelos con codificaciones de configuración regional de 8 bits heredadas. Los módulos estándar Unicode::Collate y Unicode::Collate::Locale ofrecen soluciones mucho más poderosas para los problemas de clasificación.

$. is reset when the filehandle is closed, but not when an open filehandle is reopened without an intervening close(). For more details, see I/O Operators in perlop. Because <> never does an explicit close, line numbers increase across ARGV files (but see examples in eof).

Para obtener más detalles, consulte Operadores de E / S en perlop . Debido a que <> nunca realiza un cierre explícito, los números de línea aumentan en los archivos ARGV (pero vea los ejemplos en eof ).

trans-unit.source: $. is reset when the filehandle is closed, but not when an open filehandle is reopened without an intervening close(). For more details, see "I/O Operators" in perlop. $@ is set if the string to be eval-ed did not compile (this may happen if open or close were imported with bad prototypes), or if Perl code executed during evaluation die()d. In these cases the value of $@ is the compile error, or the argument to die (which will interpolate $! and $? ). (See also Fatal, though.)
trans-unit.target: $@ se establece si la cadena a eval uar -ed no se compiló (esto puede suceder si open o close se importaron con prototipos incorrectos), o si el código Perl se ejecutó durante la evaluación die() d. En estos casos, el valor de $@ es el error de compilación, o el argumento para die (que interpolará $! Y $? ). (Ver también Fatal , sin embargo).

trans-unit.source: $^X doesn't always contain a full path in FreeBSD
$_ is a global variable.

$_ is by default a global variable. However, as of perl v5.10.0, you can use a lexical version of $_ by declaring it in a file or in a block with my. Moreover, declaring our $_ restores the global $_ in the current scope. Though this seemed like a good idea at the time it was introduced, lexical $_ actually causes more problems than it solves. If you call a function that expects to be passed information via $_ , it may or may not work, depending on how the function is written, there not being any easy way to solve this. Just avoid lexical $_ , unless you are feeling particularly masochistic. For this reason lexical $_ is still experimental and will produce a warning unless warnings have been disabled. As with other experimental features, the behavior of lexical $_ is subject to change without notice, including change into a fatal error.
trans-unit.target: $_ es por defecto una variable global. Sin embargo, a partir de perl v5.10.0, puede usar una versión léxica de $_ declarándola en un archivo o en un bloque con my . Además, declarar our $_ restaura el $_ global en el ámbito actual. Aunque esto parecía una buena idea en el momento en que se introdujo, el léxico $_ en realidad causa más problemas de los que resuelve. Si llama a una función que espera que se le pase información a través de $_ , puede que funcione o no, dependiendo de cómo esté escrita la función, no hay una manera fácil de resolver esto. Simplemente evite el léxico $_ , a menos que se sienta particularmente masoquista. Por esta razón léxico $_ todavía es experimental y producirá una advertencia a menos que se hayan desactivado las advertencias. Al igual que con otras características experimentales, el comportamiento del léxico $_ está sujeto a cambios sin previo aviso, incluido el cambio a un error fatal.

$a and $b are implicitly local to the sort() execution and regain their former values upon completing the sort.

$a and $b are set as package globals in the package the sort() is called from. That means $main::a and $main::b (or $::a and $::b) in the main package, $FooPack::a and $FooPack::b in the FooPack package, etc. If the sort block is in scope of a my or state declaration of $a and/or $b, you

$a[1] is one of these references. It refers to an array, the array containing (4, 5, 6) , and because it is a reference to an array, Use Rule 2 says that we can write $a[1]->[2] to get the third element from that array. $a[1]->[2] is the 6. Similarly, $a[0]->[1] is the 2. What we have here is like a two-dimensional array; you can write $a[ROW]->[COLUMN] to get or set the element in any row and any column of the array.
trans-unit.target: $a[1] es una de estas referencias. Se refiere a una matriz, la matriz que contiene (4, 5, 6) , y debido a que es una referencia a una matriz, Use Rule 2 dice que podemos escribir $a[1]->[2] para obtener el tercer elemento de esa matriz. $a[1]->[2] es el 6. De manera similar, $a[0]->[1] es el 2. Lo que tenemos aquí es como una matriz bidimensional; puede escribir $a[ROW]->[COLUMN] para obtener o establecer el elemento en cualquier fila y columna de la matriz.

trans-unit.source: $a[1] is one of these references. It refers to an array, the array containing (4, 5, 6), and because it is a reference to an array, Use Rule 2 says that we can write $a[1]->[2] to get the third element from that array. $a[1]->[2] is the 6. Similarly, $a[0]->[1] is the 2. What we have here is like a two-dimensional array; you can write $a[ROW]->[COLUMN] to get or set the element in any row and any column of the array.

$bar . The one that was stuffed away by local() and which will be restored when the block ends. Because variables are accessed through the typeglob, you can use *foo = *bar to create an alias which can be localized. (But be aware that this means you can't have a separate @foo and @bar , etc.)
trans-unit.target: $bar . El que fue eliminado por local() y que se restaurará cuando finalice el bloque. Debido a que se accede a las variables a través de typeglob, puede usar *foo = *bar para crear un alias que se puede localizar. (Pero tenga en cuenta que esto significa que no puede tener un @foo y @bar separados , etc.)

trans-unit.source: $bar. The one that was stuffed away by local() and which will be restored when the block ends. Because variables are accessed through the typeglob, you can use *foo = *bar to create an alias which can be localized. (But be aware that this means you can't have a separate @foo and @bar, etc.)

trans-unit.source: $coll->le($str, "abc\x{FFFF}") works like $coll->lt($str, "abd") almost, but the latter has a problem that you should know which letter is next to c . For a certain language where ch as the next letter, "abch" is greater than "abc\x{FFFF}" , but less than "abd" .
trans-unit.target: $coll->le($str, "abc\x{FFFF}") funciona como $coll->lt($str, "abd") casi, pero este último tiene un problema de que debes saber qué letra está al lado c . Para un determinado idioma en el que ch es la siguiente letra, "abch" es mayor que "abc\x{FFFF}" , pero menor que "abd" .

$filepath is the input POD to read and $outputpath is where to write POD syntax error messages. Either argument may be a scalar indicating a file-path, or else a reference to an open filehandle. If unspecified, the input-file it defaults to \*STDIN , and the output-file defaults to \*STDERR .

$hDevice is a Win32 native file handle to a device [return value from CreateFile].
$hFile is a Win32 native file handle that is already open to the file or device to be written to.
$hFile is a Win32 native file handle that is already open to the file or device to read from.
$hFile is a Win32 native file handle.

$hModel is 0 [or [], both of which mean NULL] or a Win32 native handle opened with GENERIC_READ access to a model file from which file attributes and extended attributes are to be copied if a new file gets created.
$hModelFile should contain a handle opened with GENERIC_READ access to a model file from which file attributes and extended attributes are to be copied. Or $hModelFile can be 0 [the default].
$hNativeHandle is an open Win32 native file handle, probably the return value from CreateFile or createFile.
$hNativeHandle is set to INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE [and lastFileError() and $^E are set] if FdGetOsFHandle fails. See also GetOsFHandle which provides a friendlier interface.
$hNativeHandle is set to a false value [and lastFileError() and $^E are set] if GetOsFHandle fails. GetOsFHandle returns "0 but true" in the impossible(?) case of the handle having a value of 0.
$hObject is an open Win32 native file handle or an open Win32 native handle to some other type of object.

trans-unit.source: $ioivOffsetHigh can be [] [for NULL] to indicate that you are only specifying a 4-byte offset and the resulting file position will be 0xFFFFFFFE or less [just under 4GB]. Otherwise $ioivOfffsetHigh starts out with the high-order 4 bytes [signed] of the offset and gets set to the [unsigned] high-order 4 bytes of the resulting file position.
$isdst is true if the specified time occurs during Daylight Saving Time, false otherwise.
trans-unit.target: $isdst es verdadero si la hora especificada ocurre durante el horario de verano, falso en caso contrario.

trans-unit.source: $ivFD will be non-negative if the open operation was successful. For failure, -1 is returned and $! [and possibly fileLastError() and $^E] is set to the reason for the failure.

$ivOffset is [if $ioivOffsetHigh is []] the offset [in bytes] to the new file position from the position specified via $uFromWhere. If $ioivOffsetHigh is not [], then $ivOffset is converted to an unsigned value to be used as the low-order 4 bytes of the offset.
$lBufSize is the size of the buffer to allocate to store this list of strings. 26*4+1 is always sufficient and should usually be used.

$lBytes is the number of bytes you would like to read. $opBuffer is automatically initialized to have a buffer large enough to hold that many bytes. Unlike other buffer sizes, $lBytes does not need to have a "=" prepended to it to prevent a larger value to be passed to the underlying Win32 ReadFile API. However, a leading "=" will be silently ignored, even if Perl warnings are enabled.

$lBytes is the number of bytes you would like to write. If $pBuffer is not at least $lBytes long, WriteFile croaks. You can specify 0 for $lBytes to write length($pBuffer) bytes. A leading "=" on $lBytes will be silently ignored, even if Perl warnings are enabled.
$lTargetBuf is the size [in bytes] of the buffer to allocate for $osTargetPath. See "Buffer Sizes" for more information.
$length bytes. The only circumstances that this function will not is if end-of-file or an IO error is encountered.
trans-unit.target: $length bytes. Las únicas circunstancias en las que esta función no lo hará es si se encuentra un error de fin de archivo o de E / S.

trans-unit.source: $locale_name may be suffixed with a Unicode script code (four-letter), a Unicode region (territory) code, a Unicode language variant code. These codes are case-insensitive, and separated with '_' or '-'. E.g. en_US for English in USA, az_Cyrl for Azerbaijani in the Cyrillic script, es_ES_traditional for Spanish in Spain (Traditional).
$m is currently just a copy of the original number. The relation between $e and $m will stay always the same, though their real values might change.
trans-unit.target: $m es actualmente solo una copia del número original. La relación entre $e y $m permanecerá siempre igual, aunque sus valores reales pueden cambiar.

trans-unit.target: $name siempre es opcional.

trans-unit.source: $olOutLength is the number of bytes actually written to $osBuffer but length($osBuffer) can also be used to determine this.

$olRetBytes is [] or is a scalar to receive the number of bytes written to $opOutBuf. Even when $olRetBytes is [], a valid pointer to a DWORD [and not NULL] is passed to DeviceIoControl. In this case, [] just means that you don't care about the value that might be written to $olRetBytes, which is usually the case since you can usually use length($opOutBuf) instead.
$olTargetLen is set to the number of bytes written to $osTargetPath but you can also use length($osTargetPath) to determine this.
$opBuffer will be set to a string containing the bytes read.

$opOutBuf is [] [for NULL] or will be set to contain a returned data structure packed into a string. $lOutBuf indicates how much space to allocate in $opOutBuf for DeviceIoControl to store the data structure. If $lOutBuf is a number and $opOutBuf already has a buffer allocated for it that is larger than $lOutBuf bytes, then this larger buffer size will be passed to DeviceIoControl. However, you can force a specific buffer size to be passed to DeviceIoControl by prepending a "=" to the front of $lOutBuf.
$osBuffer is a scalar to be set to contain the constructed string.

$osFsType is a scalar to be set to the string representing the file system type, such as "FAT" or "NTFS". $lFsType is the number of bytes to allocate for the $osFsType buffer [see "Buffer Sizes" for more information].

$osTargetPath will be assigned a string containing the list of definitions. The definitions are each '\0'-terminate and are concatenated into the string, most recent first, with an extra '\0' at the end of the whole string [see GetLogicalDriveStrings for a sample of this format].

$osVolName is a scalar to be set to the string representing the volume name, also called the file system label. $lVolName is the number of bytes to allocate for the $osVolName buffer [see "Buffer Sizes" for more information].
$ouBytesWritten will be set to the actual number of bytes written unless you specify it as [].

$ouFlags will be set to an unsigned value having zero or more of the bits HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT and HANDLE_FLAG_PROTECT_FROM_CLOSE set. See the ":HANDLE_FLAG_" export class for the meanings of these bits.
$ouFsFlags is [] [for NULL] or will be set to an unsigned integer with bits set indicating properties of the file system:
$ouMaxNameLen is [] [for NULL] or will be set to the maximum length allowed for a file name or directory name within the file system.
$ouSerialNum is [] [for NULL] or will be set to the numeric value of the volume's serial number.
$pBuffer is a string containing the bytes to be written.

$pInBuf is [] [for NULL] or a data structure packed into a string. The type of data structure depends on the $uIoControlCode value. $lInBuf is 0 or the length of the structure in $pInBuf. If $pInBuf is not [] and $lInBuf is 0, then $lInBuf will automatically be set to length($pInBuf) for you.
$pOverlapped is [] or is a OVERLAPPED structure packed into a string. This is only useful if $hDevice was opened with the FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED flag set.
$pOverlapped is [] or is a OVERLAPPED structure packed into a string. This is only useful if $hFile was opened with the FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED flag set.
$pOverlapped is [] or is an OVERLAPPED structure packed into a string. This is only useful if $hFile was opened with the FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED flag set.

$pSecAttr should either be [] [for NULL] or a SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES data structure packed into a string. For example, if $pSecDesc contains a SECURITY_DESCRIPTOR structure packed into a string, perhaps via:
$pSecurityAttributes should contain a SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES structure packed into a string or [] [the default].

$path defines the file name (which need not exist), $data the file contents, and $opt is a reference to a hash of attributes which may be used to override the default attributes (fields in the tar header), which are described above in the Accessors section.
trans-unit.target: $path define el nombre del archivo (que no necesita existir), $data el contenido del archivo, y $opt es una referencia a un hash de atributos que se pueden usar para anular los atributos predeterminados (campos en el encabezado tar), que se describen arriba en la sección Accesores.

trans-unit.source: $perms is the file permissions bits to use if new database files are created. This parameter is mandatory even when not creating a new database. The permissions will be reduced by the user's umask so the usual value here would be 0666, or if some very private data then 0600. (See umask.)
trans-unit.target: $perms son los bits de permisos de archivo que se utilizarán si se crean nuevos archivos de base de datos. Este parámetro es obligatorio incluso cuando no se crea una nueva base de datos. Los permisos se reducirán por la umask del usuario, por lo que el valor habitual aquí sería 0666, o si algunos datos son muy privados, entonces 0600. (Consulte umask ).

trans-unit.source: $perms is the file permissions bits to use if new database files are created. This parameter is mandatory even when not creating a new database. The permissions will be reduced by the user's umask so the usual value here would be 0666, or if some very private data then 0600. (See "umask" in perlfunc.)

$priority can specify a level, or a level and a facility. Levels and facilities can be given as strings or as macros. When using the eventlog mechanism, priorities DEBUG and INFO are mapped to event type informational , NOTICE and WARNING to warning and ERR to EMERG to error .
trans-unit.target: $priority puede especificar un nivel, o un nivel y una instalación. Los niveles y las facilidades se pueden dar como cadenas o macros. Cuando se utiliza el mecanismo de eventlog , las prioridades DEBUG e INFO se asignan al tipo de evento informational , NOTICE y WARNING a warning y ERR a EMERG a error .

trans-unit.source: $priority can specify a level, or a level and a facility. Levels and facilities can be given as strings or as macros. When using the eventlog mechanism, priorities DEBUG and INFO are mapped to event type informational, NOTICE and WARNING to warning and ERR to EMERG to error.

trans-unit.target: $replacement puede ser un CODEREF , tomando la parte coincidente como un argumento y devolviendo una cadena para reemplazar la parte coincidente (un poco similar a s/(..)/$coderef->($1)/e ).

$replacement can be a CODEREF, taking the matching part as an argument, and returning a string to replace the matching part (a bit similar to s/(..)/$coderef->($1)/eg).

$rvhvOptions is a reference to a hash where any keys must be from the list qw( Access Create Share Attributes Flags Security Model ). The meaning of the value depends on the key name, as described below. Any option values in $rvhvOptions override the settings from $svAccess and $svShare if they conflict.
$sAccess should be a string of zero or more characters from "qrw" specifying the type of access desired: "query" or 0, "read" or GENERIC_READ [the default], or "write" or GENERIC_WRITE.

$sCreate should be a string containing zero or one character from "ktn" and zero or one character from "ce". These stand for "Keep if exists", "Truncate if exists", "New file only", "Create if none", and "Existing file only". These are translated into a $uCreate value.
$sDosDeviceName is the name of a DOS device for which we'd like to add or delete a definition.

$sDosDeviceName is the name of the "DOS" device whose definitions we want. For example, "C:", "COM1", or "PhysicalDrive0". If $sDosDeviceName is [] [for NULL], the list of all DOS device names is returned instead.

$sMode is string of zero or more letters from "rwatb". These are translated into a combination O_RDONLY ["r"], O_WRONLY ["w"], O_RDWR ["rw"], O_APPEND ["a"], O_TEXT ["t"], and O_BINARY ["b"] flags [see the Fcntl module] that is passed to OsFHandleOpenFd. Currently only O_APPEND and O_TEXT have any significance.

$sOldFileName is the path to the file to be copied. $sNewFileName is the path to where the file should be copied. Note that you can NOT just specify a path to a directory in $sNewFileName to copy the file to that directory using the same file name.

$sPath can start with "//./" to indicate that the rest of the path is the name of a "DOS device." You can use QueryDosDevice to list all current DOS devices and can add or delete them with DefineDosDevice. If you get the source-code distribution of this module from CPAN, then it includes an example script,
$sPath can use "/" or "\\" as path delimiters and can even mix the two. We will usually only use "/" in our examples since using "\\" is usually harder to read.
$sPath is the path to the file [or device, etc.] to be opened.
$sPath is the path to the file [or device, etc.] to be opened. See CreateFile for more information on possible special values for $sPath.
$sRootPath is a string specifying the path to the root of the file system, for example, "C:/".
$sShare should be a string with zero or more characters from "rwd" that is translated into a $uShare value. "rw" is the default.

$sTargetPath is the DOS device's specific definition that you wish to add or delete. For DDD_RAW_TARGET_PATH, these usually start with "\\Device\\". If the DDD_RAW_TARGET_PATH bit is not set, then $sTargetPath is just an ordinary path to some file or directory, providing the functionality of the subst command.
$size bytes.
trans-unit.target: $size bytes.

trans-unit.source: $source is a TAP::Parser::Source.
$string is used as a string under character semantics (see
trans-unit.target: $string se usa como una cadena en la semántica de caracteres (ver

trans-unit.source: $string is used as a string under character semantics (see perlunicode).

$svAccess can be a number containing the bit mask representing the specific type(s) of access to the file that you desire. See the $uAccess parameter to CreateFile for more information on these values.

$svAccess is designed to be "do what I mean", so you can skip the rest of its explanation unless you are interested in the complex details. Note that, if you want write access to a device, you need to specify "k" [and perhaps "e", as in "w ke" or "rw ke"] since Win32 suggests OPEN_EXISTING be used when opening a device.

$svShare controls how the file is shared, that is, whether other processes can have read, write, and/or delete access to the file while we have it opened. $svShare will usually be a string containing zero or more characters from "rwd" but can also be a numeric bit mask.
$swDeviceName is Unicode and Unicode is written to $oswTargetPath. $lwTargetBuf and $olwTargetLen are measured as number of WCHARs.
$swDosDeviceName and $swTargetPath are Unicode.
$swFileName is Unicode.
$swOldFileName and $swNewFileName are Unicode strings.
$swOldName and $swNewName are Unicode.
$swPath is Unicode.
$swRootPath is Unicode and Unicode is written to $oswVolName and $oswFsType. $lwVolName and $lwFsType are measures as number of WCHARs.
$swRootPath is Unicode.

$uAccess is an unsigned value with bits set indicating the type of access desired. Usually either 0 ["query" access], GENERIC_READ, GENERIC_WRITE, GENERIC_READ|GENERIC_WRITE, or GENERIC_ALL. More specific types of access can be specified, such as FILE_APPEND_DATA or FILE_READ_EA.
$uAccess should be an unsigned value containing bits set to indicate the type of access desired. GENERIC_READ is the default.
$uCreate is one of the following values: OPEN_ALWAYS, OPEN_EXISTING, TRUNCATE_EXISTING, CREATE_ALWAYS, and CREATE_NEW.
$uCreate should be one of OPEN_ALWAYS, OPEN_EXISTING, TRUNCATE_EXISTING, CREATE_ALWAYS, or CREATE_NEW.
$uFlags is an unsigned value having any of the FILE_FLAG_* or FILE_ATTRIBUTE_* bits set. Any FILE_ATTRIBUTE_* bits set via the Attributes option are logically ored with these bits. Defaults to 0.

$uFlags is an unsigned value having zero or more of the bits HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT and HANDLE_FLAG_PROTECT_FROM_CLOSE set. For each bit set in $uMask, the corresponding bit in the handle's flags is set to the value of the corresponding bit in $uFlags.
$uFlags is an unsigned value with zero or more bits set indicating attributes to associate with the file [FILE_ATTRIBUTE_* values] or special options [FILE_FLAG_* values].
$uFlags is an unsigned value with zero or more of the following bits set:

$uFromWhere is either FILE_BEGIN, FILE_CURRENT, or FILE_END, indicating that the new file position is being specified relative to the beginning of the file, the current file pointer, or the end of the file, respectively.
$uIoControlCode is an unsigned value [a IOCTL_* or FSCTL_* constant] indicating the type query or other operation to be performed.
$uMask is an unsigned value having one or more of the bits HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT and HANDLE_FLAG_PROTECT_FROM_CLOSE set. Only bits set in $uMask will be modified by SetHandleInformation.
$uMediaType if the type of media to be formatted. Mostly used to specify the density to use when formatting a floppy diskette. See the ":MEDIA_TYPE" export class for more information.
$uMode the logical combination of zero or more O_* constants exported by the Fcntl module. Currently only O_APPEND and O_TEXT have any significance.

$uShare controls how the file is shared, that is, whether other processes can have read, write, and/or delete access to the file while we have it opened. $uShare is an unsigned value with zero or more of these bits set: FILE_SHARE_READ, FILE_SHARE_WRITE, and FILE_SHARE_DELETE.
$uShare should be an unsigned value having zero or more of the following bits set: FILE_SHARE_READ, FILE_SHARE_WRITE, and FILE_SHARE_DELETE. FILE_SHARE_READ|FILE_SHARE_WRITE is the default.
$uStartLow and $ivStartHigh
$uStartOffsetLow and $ivStartOffsetHigh

trans-unit.target: $wday es el día de la semana, con 0 indicando domingo y 3 indicando miércoles. $yday es el día del año, en el rango 0..364 (o 0..365 en años bisiestos).

%table is an ordinary hash, and we get a list of keys from it, sort the keys, and loop over the keys as usual. The only use of references is in line 10. $table{$country} looks up the key $country in the hash and gets the value, which is a reference to an array of cities in that country. Use Rule 1 says that we can recover the array by saying @{$table{$country}} . Line 10 is just like

<=> sort operators. It is possible to make multiple passes over your data, building indices to make the upcoming sort more efficient, and to use what is known as the OM (Orcish Maneuver) to cache the sort keys in advance. The cache lookup, while a good idea, can itself be a source of slowdown by enforcing a double pass over the data - once to setup the cache, and once to sort the data. Using pack() to extract the required sort key into a consistent string can be an efficient way to build a single string to compare, instead of using multiple sort keys, which makes it possible to use the standard, written in c and fast, perl sort() function on the output, and is the basis of the GRT (Guttman Rossler Transform). Some string combinations can slow the GRT down, by just being too plain complex for its own good.
trans-unit.target: <=> operadores de clasificación. Es posible realizar varias pasadas sobre sus datos, construir índices para hacer que la clasificación siguiente sea más eficiente y usar lo que se conoce como OM (Maniobra orca) para almacenar en caché las claves de clasificación por adelantado. La búsqueda de caché, si bien es una buena idea, puede ser en sí misma una fuente de desaceleración al imponer un doble paso sobre los datos: una vez para configurar la caché y otra para ordenar los datos. Usar pack() para extraer la clave de clasificación requerida en una cadena consistente puede ser una forma eficiente de construir una sola cadena para comparar, en lugar de usar múltiples claves de clasificación, lo que hace posible usar el estándar, escrito en c y rápido, perl sort() función en la salida, y es la base de la GRT (Transformada de Guttman Rossler). Algunas combinaciones de cuerdas pueden ralentizar el GRT , simplemente por ser demasiado complejas para su propio bien.

trans-unit.source: <=> sort operators. It is possible to make multiple passes over your data, building indices to make the upcoming sort more efficient, and to use what is known as the OM (Orcish Maneuver) to cache the sort keys in advance. The cache lookup, while a good idea, can itself be a source of slowdown by enforcing a double pass over the data - once to setup the cache, and once to sort the data. Using pack() to extract the required sort key into a consistent string can be an efficient way to build a single string to compare, instead of using multiple sort keys, which makes it possible to use the standard, written in c and fast, perl sort() function on the output, and is the basis of the GRT (Guttman Rossler Transform). Some string combinations can slow the GRT down, by just being too plain complex for its own good.

trans-unit.source: (R1)(R2) ...
(bool)!!(cbool) in a ternary triggers a bug in xlc on AIX

(condition) should be one of: 1) an integer in parentheses (which is valid if the corresponding pair of parentheses matched); 2) a look-ahead/look-behind/evaluate zero-width assertion; 3) a name in angle brackets or single quotes (which is valid if a group with the given name matched); or 4) the special symbol (R) (true when evaluated inside of recursion or eval). Additionally the R may be followed by a number, (which will be true when evaluated when recursing inside of the appropriate group), or by &NAME , in which case it will be true only when evaluated during recursion in the named group.
trans-unit.target: (condition) debe ser uno de: 1) un número entero entre paréntesis (que es válido si el par de paréntesis correspondiente coincide); 2) una aserción de anticipación / retroceso / evaluación de ancho cero; 3) un nombre entre paréntesis angulares o comillas simples (que es válido si un grupo con el nombre de pila coincide); o 4) el símbolo especial (R) (verdadero cuando se evalúa dentro de la recursividad o eval). Además, la R puede ir seguida de un número (que será verdadero cuando se evalúe cuando se repita dentro del grupo apropiado), o por &NAME , en cuyo caso será verdadero solo cuando se evalúe durante la recursión en el grupo nombrado.

trans-unit.source: *foo{IO} is an alternative to the *HANDLE mechanism given in "Typeglobs and Filehandles" in perldata for passing filehandles into or out of subroutines, or storing into larger data structures. Its disadvantage is that it won't create a new filehandle for you. Its advantage is that you have less risk of clobbering more than you want to with a typeglob assignment. (It still conflates file and directory handles, though.) However, if you assign the incoming value to a scalar instead of a typeglob as we do in the examples below, there's no risk of that happening.

*foo{IO} is an alternative to the *HANDLE mechanism given in Typeglobs and Filehandles in perldata for passing filehandles into or out of subroutines, or storing into larger data structures. Its disadvantage is that it won't create a new filehandle for you. Its advantage is that you have less risk of clobbering more than you want to with a typeglob assignment. (It still conflates file and directory handles, though.) However, if you assign the incoming value to a scalar instead of a typeglob as we do in the examples below, there's no risk of that happening.
trans-unit.target: *foo{IO} es una alternativa al mecanismo *HANDLE dado en Typeglobs y Filehandles en perldata para pasar identificadores de archivos dentro o fuera de subrutinas, o almacenar en estructuras de datos más grandes. Su desventaja es que no creará un nuevo identificador de archivo para usted. Su ventaja es que tiene menos riesgo de golpear más de lo que desea con una asignación de typeglob. (Sin embargo, aún combina los identificadores de archivos y directorios). Sin embargo, si asigna el valor entrante a un escalar en lugar de a un typeglob como lo hacemos en los ejemplos siguientes, no hay riesgo de que eso suceda.

trans-unit.source: *foo{NAME} and *foo{PACKAGE} are the exception, in that they return strings, rather than references. These return the package and name of the typeglob itself, rather than one that has been assigned to it. So, after *foo=*Foo::bar , *foo will become "*Foo::bar" when used as a string, but *foo{PACKAGE} and *foo{NAME} will continue to produce "main" and "foo", respectively.
trans-unit.target: *foo{NAME} y *foo{PACKAGE} son la excepción, ya que devuelven cadenas, en lugar de referencias. Estos devuelven el paquete y el nombre del typeglob en sí, en lugar de uno que se le ha asignado. Entonces, después de *foo=*Foo::bar , *foo se convertirá en "* Foo :: bar" cuando se use como una cadena, pero *foo{PACKAGE} y *foo{NAME} continuarán produciendo "principal" y " foo ", respectivamente.

trans-unit.source: *foo{NAME} and *foo{PACKAGE} are the exception, in that they return strings, rather than references. These return the package and name of the typeglob itself, rather than one that has been assigned to it. So, after *foo=*Foo::bar, *foo will become "*Foo::bar" when used as a string, but *foo{PACKAGE} and *foo{NAME} will continue to produce "main" and "foo", respectively.

*foo{THING} returns undef if that particular THING hasn't been used yet, except in the case of scalars. *foo{SCALAR} returns a reference to an anonymous scalar if $foo hasn't been used yet. This might change in a future release.
trans-unit.target: *foo{THING} devuelve undef si esa COSA en particular no se ha utilizado todavía, excepto en el caso de los escalares. *foo{SCALAR} devuelve una referencia a un escalar anónimo si aún no se ha utilizado $ foo. Esto podría cambiar en una versión futura.

/x but NOT /xx is turned on for matching foo. (One might mistakenly think that since the inner (?x) is already in the scope of /x, that the result would effectively be the sum of them, yielding /xx. It doesn't work that way.) Similarly, doing something like (?xx-x)foo turns off all "x" behavior for matching foo, it is not that you subtract 1 "x" from 2 to get 1 "x" remaining.
/x lets you turn this:
trans-unit.target: /x te permite convertir esto:

trans-unit.source: /x tells the regular expression parser to ignore most whitespace that is neither backslashed nor within a bracketed character class. You can use this to break up your regular expression into (slightly) more readable parts. Also, the # character is treated as a metacharacter introducing a comment that runs up to the pattern's closing delimiter, or to the end of the current line if the pattern extends onto the next line. Hence, this is very much like an ordinary Perl code comment. (You can include the closing delimiter within the comment only if you precede it with a backslash, so be careful!)
trans-unit.target: /x le dice al analizador de expresiones regulares que ignore la mayoría de los espacios en blanco que no tienen barra invertida ni están dentro de una clase de caracteres entre corchetes. Puede usar esto para dividir su expresión regular en partes (un poco) más legibles. Además, el carácter # se trata como un metacarácter que introduce un comentario que se extiende hasta el delimitador de cierre del patrón o hasta el final de la línea actual si el patrón se extiende a la línea siguiente. Por lo tanto, esto es muy parecido a un comentario de código Perl ordinario. (Puede incluir el delimitador de cierre dentro del comentario solo si lo precede con una barra invertida, ¡así que tenga cuidado!)

trans-unit.source: :loose slows down look-ups by a factor of 2 to 3 versus :full , but the trade-off may be worth it to you. Each individual look-up takes very little time, and the results are cached, so the speed difference would become a factor only in programs that do look-ups of many different spellings, and probably only when those look-ups are through vianame() and string_vianame() , since \N{...} look-ups are done at compile time.
trans-unit.target: :loose ralentiza las búsquedas en un factor de 2 a 3 frente a :full , pero la compensación puede valer la pena. Cada búsqueda individual toma muy poco tiempo y los resultados se almacenan en caché, por lo que la diferencia de velocidad se convertiría en un factor solo en los programas que realizan búsquedas de muchas ortografías diferentes, y probablemente solo cuando esas búsquedas se realizan a través de vianame() y string_vianame() , ya que las búsquedas de \N{...} se realizan en tiempo de compilación.

trans-unit.source: :loose slows down look-ups by a factor of 2 to 3 versus :full, but the trade-off may be worth it to you. Each individual look-up takes very little time, and the results are cached, so the speed difference would become a factor only in programs that do look-ups of many different spellings, and probably only when those look-ups are through vianame() and string_vianame(), since \N{...} look-ups are done at compile time.

trans-unit.source: :std is not a layer but an additional subpragma. When specified in the import list, it activates an additional functionality of pushing the layers selected for input/output handles to the standard filehandles (STDIN, STDOUT, STDERR). If the new layers and existing layer stack both end with an :encoding layer, the existing :encoding layer will also be removed.
:via(MODULE) allows a transformation to be applied by an arbitrary Perl module, for example compression / decompression, encryption / decryption. See PerlIO::via for more information.

; before executing your program. You can use quotes to add extra code after the module name, e.g., '-MMODULE qw(foo bar)'.
trans-unit.target: ; antes de ejecutar su programa. Puede usar comillas para agregar código adicional después del nombre del módulo, por ejemplo, '-MMODULE qw(foo bar)' .

trans-unit.source: lock follows references exactly
trans-unit.target: lock sigue exactamente las referencias

trans-unit.source: lock places a advisory lock on a variable until the lock goes out of scope. If the variable is locked by another thread, the lock call will block until it's available. Multiple calls to lock by the same thread from within dynamically nested scopes are safe -- the variable will remain locked until the outermost lock on the variable goes out of scope.
trans-unit.target: lock coloca unbloqueo de aviso en una variable hasta que el bloqueo se sale de su alcance. Si la variable está bloqueada por otro hilo, lallamada de lock se bloqueará hasta que esté disponible. Varias llamadas para lock por el mismo hilo desde dentro de alcances anidados dinámicamente son seguras: la variable permanecerá bloqueada hasta que el bloqueo más externo de la variable salga del alcance.

trans-unit.source: log(-inf) is highly weird. Since log(-x)=pi*i+log(x), then log(-inf)=pi*i+inf. However, since the imaginary part is finite, the real infinity "overshadows" it, so the number might as well just be infinity. However, the result is a complex number, and since BigInt/BigFloat can only have real numbers as results, the result is NaN.
trans-unit.target: log(-inf) es muy extraño. Dado que log (-x) = pi * i + log (x), entonces log (-inf) = pi * i + inf. Sin embargo, dado que la parte imaginaria es finita, el infinito real la "eclipsa", por lo que el número también podría ser infinito. Sin embargo, el resultado es un número complejo, y dado que BigInt / BigFloat solo puede tener números reales como resultados, el resultado es NaN.

trans-unit.source: open accepts one, two or three parameters. With one parameter, it is just a front end for the built-in open function. With two or three parameters, the first parameter is a filename that may include whitespace or other special characters, and the second parameter is the open mode, optionally followed by a file permission value.
trans-unit.target: open acepta uno, dos o tres parámetros. Con un parámetro, es solo una interfaz para lafunción open incorporada. Con dos o tres parámetros, el primer parámetro es un nombre de archivo que puede incluir espacios en blanco u otros caracteres especiales, y el segundo parámetro es el modo abierto, seguido opcionalmente por un valor de permiso de archivo.

trans-unit.source: evaled strings (when accessible) are considered to be filenames: f (eval 7) and f eval 7\b access the body of the 7th evaled string (in the order of execution). The bodies of the currently executed eval and of evaled strings that define subroutines are saved and thus accessible.

Los cuerpos de la eval actualmente ejecutaday de lascadenas eval uadas que definen subrutinas se guardan y, por lo tanto, se puede acceder a ellas.

trans-unit.source: join() does three things: it waits for a thread to exit, cleans up after it, and returns any data the thread may have produced. But what if you're not interested in the thread's return values, and you don't really care when the thread finishes? All you want is for the thread to get cleaned up after when it's done.
trans-unit.target: join() hace tres cosas: espera a que un subproceso salga, limpia después de él y devuelve cualquier dato que el subproceso haya producido. Pero, ¿qué pasa si no está interesado en los valores de retorno del hilo y realmente no le importa cuándo termina el hilo? Todo lo que desea es que el hilo se limpie después de que esté listo.

trans-unit.source: join waits for a thread to end and returns any values the thread exited with. join will block until the thread has ended, though it won't block if the thread has already terminated.
trans-unit.target: join espera a que termine un hilo y devuelve los valores con los que salió el hilo. join se bloqueará hasta que el hilo haya terminado, aunque no se bloqueará si el hilo ya ha terminado.

trans-unit.source: kill() doesn't have the semantics of raise() , i.e. it doesn't send a signal to the identified process like it does on Unix platforms. Instead kill($sig, $pid) terminates the process identified by $pid , and makes it exit immediately with exit status $sig. As in Unix, if $sig is 0 and the specified process exists, it returns true without actually terminating it. (Win32)
trans-unit.target: kill() no tiene la semántica de raise() , es decir, no envía una señal al proceso identificado como lo hace en las plataformas Unix. En cambio, kill($sig, $pid) finaliza el proceso identificado por $pid y lo hace salir inmediatamente con el estado de salida $ sig. Como en Unix, si $ sig es 0 y el proceso especificado existe, devuelve verdadero sin terminarlo. (Win32)

trans-unit.source: kill('KILL', ...) can be used to terminate a pseudo-process by passing it the ID returned by fork(). The outcome of kill on a pseudo-process is unpredictable and it should not be used except under dire circumstances, because the operating system may not guarantee integrity of the process resources when a running thread is terminated. The process which implements the pseudo-processes can be blocked and the Perl interpreter hangs. Note that using kill('KILL', ...) on a pseudo-process() may typically cause memory leaks, because the thread that implements the pseudo-process does not get a chance to clean up its resources.
trans-unit.target: kill('KILL', ...) se puede usar para terminar un pseudoproceso pasándole el ID devuelto por fork (). El resultado de la eliminación de un pseudoproceso es impredecible y no debe usarse excepto en circunstancias extremas, porque el sistema operativo puede no garantizar la integridad de los recursos del proceso cuando se termina un subproceso en ejecución. El proceso que implementa los pseudoprocesos puede bloquearse y el intérprete de Perl se bloquea. Tenga en cuenta que el uso de kill('KILL', ...) en un pseudoproceso () normalmente puede causar pérdidas de memoria, porque el hilo que implementa el pseudoproceso no tiene la oportunidad de limpiar sus recursos.

trans-unit.source: kill('TERM', ...) can also be used on pseudo-processes, but the signal will not be delivered while the pseudo-process is blocked by a system call, e.g. waiting for a socket to connect, or trying to read from a socket with no data available. Starting in Perl 5.14 the parent process will not wait for children to exit once they have been signalled with kill('TERM', ...) to avoid deadlock during process exit. You will have to explicitly call waitpid() to make sure the child has time to clean-up itself, but you are then also responsible that the child is not blocking on I/O either.
trans-unit.target: kill('TERM', ...) también se puede usar en pseudoprocesos, pero la señal no se entregará mientras el pseudoproceso esté bloqueado por una llamada al sistema, por ejemplo, esperando a que un conector se conecte o tratando de leer desde un enchufe sin datos disponibles. A partir de Perl 5.14, el proceso padre no esperará a que los niños salgan una vez que hayan sido señalados con kill('TERM', ...) para evitar un punto muerto durante la salida del proceso. Tendrá que llamar explícitamente a waitpid () para asegurarse de que el niño tenga tiempo para limpiarse por sí mismo, pero también es responsable de que el niño tampoco bloquee las E / S.

trans-unit.source: kill(-9, $pid) will terminate the process specified by $pid and recursively all child processes owned by it. This is different from the Unix semantics, where the signal will be delivered to all processes in the same process group as the process specified by $pid. (Win32)
trans-unit.target: kill(-9, $pid) terminará el proceso especificado por $pid y de forma recursiva todos los procesos secundarios que le pertenecen. Esto es diferente de la semántica de Unix, donde la señal se entregará a todos los procesos en el mismo grupo de procesos que el proceso especificado por $ pid. (Win32)

trans-unit.source: last cannot be used to exit a block that returns a value such as eval {} , sub {} , or do {} , and should not be used to exit a grep() or map() operation.

trans-unit.source: my($x) creates a new variable that is only visible in the current subroutine. This is done at compile-time, so it is called lexical or static scoping. my() always affects private variables, also called lexical variables or (improperly) static(ly scoped) variables.
trans-unit.target: my($x) crea una nueva variable que solo es visible en la subrutina actual. Esto se realiza en tiempo de compilación, por lo que se denomina ámbito léxico o estático. my () siempre afecta a las variables privadas, también llamadas variables léxicas o (incorrectamente) variables estáticas (de ámbito ly).

trans-unit.source: my() and local() give list context to the right hand side of = . The <$fh> read operation, like so many of Perl's functions and operators, can tell which context it was called in and behaves appropriately. In general, the scalar() function can help. This function does nothing to the data itself (contrary to popular myth) but rather tells its argument to behave in whatever its scalar fashion is. If that function doesn't have a defined scalar behavior, this of course doesn't help you (such as with sort()).
trans-unit.target: my() y local() dan contexto de lista al lado derecho de = . La operación de lectura <$ fh>, como muchas de las funciones y operadores de Perl, puede decir en qué contexto se llamó y se comporta de manera apropiada. En general, la función escalar () puede ayudar. Esta función no hace nada con los datos en sí (contrariamente al mito popular), sino que le dice a su argumento que se comporte de la forma que sea escalar. Si esa función no tiene un comportamiento escalar definido, esto por supuesto no le ayuda (como con sort ()).

trans-unit.source: my variables are scoped to the current block, not to the current function. If you write {my $x;} $x; , the second $x does not refer to the one declared inside the block.
trans-unit.target: my variables tienen como alcance el bloque actual, no la función actual. Si escribe {my $x;} $x; , el segundo $x no se refiere al declarado dentro del bloque.

For this reason, if you are potentially using Unicode in your program, the use feature 'unicode_strings' subpragma is strongly recommended.
trans-unit.target: no feature 'unicode_strings' le dice al compilador que use las reglas tradicionales de Perl donde se usan las reglas del juego de caracteres nativos a menos que Perl tenga claro que se desea Unicode. Por esta razón, si potencialmente está utilizando Unicode en su programa,serecomienda encarecidamente use feature 'unicode_strings' unicode_strings ' .

trans-unit.source: our has the same scoping rules as my or state, meaning that it is only valid within a lexical scope. Unlike my and state, which both declare new (lexical) variables, our only creates an alias to an existing variable: a package variable of the same name.

trans-unit.source: pack and unpack are two functions for transforming data according to a user-defined template, between the guarded way Perl stores values and some well-defined representation as might be required in the environment of a Perl program. Unfortunately, they're also two of the most misunderstood and most often overlooked functions that Perl provides. This tutorial will demystify them for you.
trans-unit.target: pack y unpack son dos funciones para transformar datos de acuerdo con una plantilla definida por el usuario, entre la forma protegida en que Perl almacena valores y alguna representación bien definida como podría ser necesaria en el entorno de un programa Perl. Desafortunadamente, también son dos de las funciones más incomprendidas y pasadas por alto que proporciona Perl. Este tutorial los desmitificará por ti.

trans-unit.source: pos directly accesses the location used by the regexp engine to store the offset, so assigning to pos will change that offset, and so will also influence the \G zero-width assertion in regular expressions. Both of these effects take place for the next match, so you can't affect the position with pos during the current match, such as in (?{pos() = 5}) or s//pos() = 5/e .
trans-unit.target: pos accede directamente a la ubicación utilizada por el motor deexpresiones regularespara almacenar el desplazamiento, por lo que asignar a pos cambiará ese desplazamiento y, por lo tanto, también influirá en laafirmación de ancho cero de \G en las expresiones regulares. Ambos efectos tienen lugar para el próximo partido, por lo que no puede afectar la posición con pos durante el partido actual, como en (?{pos() = 5}) o s//pos() = 5/e .

trans-unit.source: use VERSION also lexically enables all features available in the requested version as defined by the feature pragma, disabling any features not in the requested version's feature bundle. See feature. Similarly, if the specified Perl version is greater than or equal to 5.12.0, strictures are enabled lexically as with use strict . Any explicit use of use strict or no strict overrides use VERSION , even if it comes before it. Later use of use VERSION will override all behavior of a previous use VERSION , possibly removing the strict and feature added by use VERSION . use VERSION does not load the
trans-unit.target: use VERSION también habilita léxicamente todas las características disponibles en la versión solicitada según lo definido por elpragma de feature , deshabilitando cualquier característica que no esté en el paquete de características de la versión solicitada. Ver característica . De manera similar, si la versión de Perl especificada es mayor o igual a 5.12.0, las restricciones se habilitan léxicamente como con el use strict . Cualquier uso explícito de use strict o no strict anulaciones estrictas use VERSION , incluso si viene antes. trans-unit.source: use feature 'fc' tells the compiler to enable the fc function, which implements Unicode casefolding.
trans-unit.target: use feature 'fc' le dice al compilador que habilite lafunción fc , que implementa el plegado de mayúsculas y minúsculas Unicode.

trans-unit.source: use feature 'say' tells the compiler to enable the Perl 6 style say function.
trans-unit.target: use feature 'say' le dice al compilador que habilite lafunción say de estilo Perl 6.

trans-unit.source: use feature 'state' tells the compiler to enable state variables.
trans-unit.target: use feature 'state' le dice al compilador que habilite state variables de estado .

trans-unit.source: use feature 'switch' tells the compiler to enable the Perl 6 given/when construct.
trans-unit.target: use feature 'switch' le dice al compilador que habilite la construcción dada / when de Perl 6.

trans-unit.source: use feature 'unicode_strings' tells the compiler to use Unicode rules in all string operations executed within its scope (unless they are also within the scope of either use locale or use bytes ). The same applies to all regular expressions compiled within the scope, even if executed outside it. It does not change the internal representation of strings, but only how they are interpreted.
trans-unit.target: use feature 'unicode_strings' le dice al compilador que use reglas Unicode en todas las operaciones de cadena ejecutadas dentro de su alcance (a menos que también estén dentro del alcance de use locale o use bytes ). Lo mismo se aplica a todas las expresiones regulares compiladas dentro del alcance, incluso si se ejecutan fuera de él. No cambia la representación interna de las cadenas, sino solo cómo se interpretan.

trans-unit.source: use re 'debug' enables you to see the gory details of how the Perl regular expression engine works. In order to understand this typically voluminous output, one must not only have some idea about how regular expression matching works in general, but also know how Perl's regular expressions are internally compiled into an automaton. These matters are explored in some detail in Debugging Regular Expressions in perldebguts.
trans-unit.target: use re 'debug' le permite ver los detalles sangrientos de cómo funciona el motor de expresiones regulares de Perl. Para entender esta salida típicamente voluminosa, uno no solo debe tener alguna idea sobre cómo funciona la coincidencia de expresiones regulares en general, sino también saber cómo las expresiones regulares de Perl se compilan internamente en un autómata. Estos temas se exploran con cierto detalle en Depurar expresiones regulares en perldebguts .

trans-unit.source: use VERSION also lexically enables all features available in the requested version as defined by the feature pragma, disabling any features not in the requested version's feature bundle. See feature. Similarly, if the specified Perl version is greater than or equal to 5.12.0, strictures are enabled lexically as with use strict . Any explicit use of use strict or no strict overrides use VERSION , even if it comes before it. Later use of use VERSION will override all behavior of a previous use VERSION , possibly removing the strict and feature added by use VERSION . use VERSION does not load the
trans-unit.target: use VERSION también habilita léxicamente todas las características disponibles en la versión solicitada según lo definido por elpragma de feature , deshabilitando cualquier característica que no esté en el paquete de características de la versión solicitada. Ver característica . De manera similar, si la versión de Perl especificada es mayor o igual a 5.12.0, las restricciones se habilitan léxicamente como con el use strict . Cualquier uso explícito de use strict o no strict anulaciones estrictas use VERSION , incluso si viene antes. trans-unit.source: Archive::Tar uses byte semantics for any files it reads from or writes to disk. This is not a problem if you only deal with files and never look at their content or work solely with byte strings. But if you use Unicode strings with character semantics, some additional steps need to be taken.
trans-unit.target: Archive::Tar usa semántica de bytes para cualquier archivo que lee o escribe en el disco. Esto no es un problema si solo maneja archivos y nunca mira su contenido o trabaja únicamente con cadenas de bytes. Pero si usa cadenas Unicode con semántica de caracteres, es necesario realizar algunos pasos adicionales.

trans-unit.source: AutoSplit will also emit general diagnostics for inability to create directories or files.
trans-unit.target: AutoSplit también emitirá diagnósticos generales para la imposibilidad de crear directorios o archivos.

trans-unit.source: AutoSplit will inform the user if it is necessary to create the top-level directory specified in the invocation. It is preferred that the script or installation process that invokes AutoSplit have created the full directory path ahead of time. This warning may indicate that the module is being split into an incorrect path.
trans-unit.target: AutoSplit informará al usuario si es necesario crear el directorio de nivel superior especificado en la invocación. Se prefiere que el script o el proceso de instalación que invoca AutoSplit haya creado la ruta completa del directorio antes de tiempo. Esta advertencia puede indicar que el módulo se está dividiendo en una ruta incorrecta.

trans-unit.source: AutoSplit will warn the user of all subroutines whose name causes potential file naming conflicts on machines with drastically limited (8 characters or less) file name length. Since the subroutine name is used as the file name, these warnings can aid in portability to such systems.
trans-unit.target: AutoSplit advertirá al usuario de todas las subrutinas cuyo nombre cause posibles conflictos de nombres de archivos en máquinas con una longitud de nombre de archivo drásticamente limitada (8 caracteres o menos). Dado que el nombre de la subrutina se utiliza como nombre de archivo, estas advertencias pueden ayudar en la portabilidad a dichos sistemas.

trans-unit.source: CLONE , CLONE_SKIP ,
trans-unit.target: CLONE , CLONE_SKIP ,

trans-unit.source: CLONE, CLONE_SKIP

CLONEf_CLONE_HOST - This is a win32 thing, it is ignored on unix, it tells perl's win32host code (which is c++) to clone itself, this is needed on win32 if you want to run two threads at the same time, if you just want to do some stuff in a separate perl interpreter and then throw it away and return to the original one, you don't need to do anything.

CLONEf_COPY_STACKS - is used to, well, copy the stacks also, without it we only clone the data and zero the stacks, with it we copy the stacks and the new perl interpreter is ready to run at the exact same point as the previous one. The pseudo-fork code uses COPY_STACKS while the threads->create doesn't.

CLONEf_KEEP_PTR_TABLE - perl_clone keeps a ptr_table with the pointer of the old variable as a key and the new variable as a value, this allows it to check if something has been cloned and not clone it again, but rather just use the value and increase the refcount. If KEEP_PTR_TABLE is not set then perl_clone will kill the ptr_table using the function ptr_table_free(PL_ptr_table); PL_ptr_table = NULL;. A reason to keep it around is if you want to dup some of your own variables which are outside the graph that perl scans.

CPAN.pm comes with a collection of example YAML files. Note that these are really just examples and should not be used without care because they cannot fit everybody's purpose. After all, the authors of the packages that ask questions had a need to ask, so you should watch their questions and adjust the examples to your environment and your needs. You have been warned:-)
trans-unit.target: CPAN.pm viene con una colección de archivos YAML de ejemplo. Tenga en cuenta que estos son realmente solo ejemplos y no deben usarse sin cuidado porque no pueden ajustarse al propósito de todos. Después de todo, los autores de los paquetes que hacen preguntas tenían la necesidad de hacer preguntas, por lo que debería observar sus preguntas y ajustar los ejemplos a su entorno y sus necesidades. Usted ha sido advertido:-)

trans-unit.source: Carp takes care not to clobber the status variables $! and $^E in the course of assembling its error messages. This means that a $SIG{__DIE__} or $SIG{__WARN__} handler can capture the error information held in those variables, if it is required to augment the error message, and if the code calling Carp left useful values there. Of course, Carp can't guarantee the latter.
trans-unit.target: Carp se cuida de no golpear las variables de estado $! y $^E en el curso de ensamblar sus mensajes de error. Esto significa que un controlador $SIG{__DIE__} o $SIG{__WARN__} puede capturar la información de error contenida en esas variables, si es necesario para aumentar el mensaje de error y si el código que llama a Carp dejó valores útiles allí. Por supuesto, Carp no puede garantizar esto último.

trans-unit.source: Class::Accessor does a lot less than Moose , and is a nice alternative if you find Moose overwhelming. It's been around a long time and is well battle-tested. It also has a minimal Moose compatibility mode which makes moving from Class::Accessor to Moose easy.
trans-unit.target: Class::Accessor hace mucho menos que Moose , y es una buena alternativa si encuentra a Moose abrumador. Ha existido durante mucho tiempo y está bien probado en batalla. También tiene un modo de compatibilidad mínimo de Moose que facilita el cambio de Class::Accessor a Moose .

trans-unit.source: Class::Accessor does a lot less than Moose, and is a nice alternative if you find Moose overwhelming. It's been around a long time and is well battle-tested. It also has a minimal Moose compatibility mode which makes moving from Class::Accessor to Moose easy.

Class::Struct can create your class at compile time. The main reason for doing this is obvious, so your class acts like every other class in Perl. Creating your class at compile time will make the order of events similar to using any other class ( or Perl module ).
trans-unit.target: Class::Struct puede crear su clase en tiempo de compilación. La razón principal para hacer esto es obvia, por lo que su clase actúa como cualquier otra clase en Perl. La creación de su clase en tiempo de compilación hará que el orden de los eventos sea similar al de cualquier otra clase (o módulo Perl).

trans-unit.source: Class::Struct exports a single function, struct . Given a list of element names and types, and optionally a class name, struct creates a Perl 5 class that implements a "struct-like" data structure.
trans-unit.target: Class::Struct exporta una sola función, struct . Dada una lista de nombres y tipos de elementos, y opcionalmente un nombre de clase, struct crea una clase de Perl 5 que implementa una estructura de datos "similar a una estructura".

trans-unit.source: Class::Struct exports a single function, struct. Given a list of element names and types, and optionally a class name, struct creates a Perl 5 class that implements a "struct-like" data structure.

Class::Tiny is the absolute minimal option. It has no dependencies, and almost no syntax to learn. It's a good option for a super minimal environment and for throwing something together quickly without having to worry about details.

trans-unit.source: DOES checks if the object or class performs the role ROLE . A role is a named group of specific behavior (often methods of particular names and signatures), similar to a class, but not necessarily a complete class by itself. For example, logging or serialization may be roles.
trans-unit.target: DOES comprueba si el objeto o la clase desempeña el rol ROLE . Un rol es un grupo con nombre de comportamiento específico (a menudo métodos de nombres y firmas particulares), similar a una clase, pero no necesariamente una clase completa por sí misma. Por ejemplo, el registro o la serialización pueden ser roles.

trans-unit.source: DOES checks if the object or class performs the role ROLE. A role is a named group of specific behavior (often methods of particular names and signatures), similar to a class, but not necessarily a complete class by itself. For example, logging or serialization may be roles.

Data::Dumper cheats with CODE references. If a code reference is encountered in the structure being processed (and if you haven't set the Deparse flag), an anonymous subroutine that contains the string '"DUMMY"' will be inserted in its place, and a warning will be printed if Purity is set. You can eval the result, but bear in mind that the anonymous sub that gets created is just a placeholder. Someday, perl will have a switch to cache-on-demand the string representation of a compiled piece of code, I hope. If you have prior knowledge of all the code refs that your data structures are likely to have, you can use the Seen method to pre-seed the internal reference table and make the dumped output point to them, instead. See EXAMPLES above.
trans-unit.target: Data::Dumper con referencias de CÓDIGO. Si se encuentra una referencia de código en la estructura que se está procesando (y si no ha configurado el indicador Deparse ), se insertará una subrutina anónima que contiene la cadena '"DUMMY"' en su lugar, y se imprimirá una advertencia si Purity está puesta. Puede eval uar el resultado, pero tenga en cuenta que el sub anónimo que se crea es solo un marcador de posición. Algún día, Perl tendrá un cambio para almacenar en caché a pedido la representación de cadena de un fragmento de código compilado, espero. Si usted tiene un conocimiento previo de todos los árbitros de código que sus estructuras de datos es probable que tengan, se puede utilizar el Seen método para pre-sembrar la tabla de referencia interna y hacer que la salida volcada apunte a ellos, en su lugar. Ver EJEMPLOS arriba.

trans-unit.source: Data::Dumper cheats with CODE references. If a code reference is encountered in the structure being processed (and if you haven't set the Deparse flag), an anonymous subroutine that contains the string '"DUMMY"' will be inserted in its place, and a warning will be printed if Purity is set. You can eval the result, but bear in mind that the anonymous sub that gets created is just a placeholder. Even using the Deparse flag will in some cases produce results that behave differently after being passed to eval; see the documentation for B::Deparse.

ExtUtils::ParseXS will compile XS code into C code by embedding the constructs necessary to let C functions manipulate Perl values and creates the glue necessary to let Perl access those functions. The compiler uses typemaps to determine how to map C function parameters and variables to Perl values.
trans-unit.target: ExtUtils::ParseXS compilará código XS en código C incrustando las construcciones necesarias para permitir que las funciones de C manipulen los valores de Perl y crea el pegamento necesario para permitir que Perl acceda a esas funciones. El compilador usa mapas de tipos para determinar cómo asignar parámetros y variables de función de C a valores de Perl.

trans-unit.source: Fatal clobbers the context in which a function is called and always makes it a scalar context, except when the :void tag is used. This problem does not exist in autodie.
trans-unit.target: Fatal golpea el contexto en el que se llama a una función y siempre lo convierte en un contexto escalar, excepto cuando se usa la etiqueta :void . Este problema no existe en autodie .

trans-unit.source: Fatal provides a way to conveniently replace functions which normally return a false value when they fail with equivalents which raise exceptions if they are not successful. This lets you use these functions without having to test their return values explicitly on each call. Exceptions can be caught using eval{}. See perlfunc and perlvar for details.
trans-unit.target: Fatal proporciona una forma de reemplazar convenientemente funciones que normalmente devuelven un valor falso cuando fallan con equivalentes que generan excepciones si no tienen éxito. Esto le permite usar estas funciones sin tener que probar sus valores de retorno explícitamente en cada llamada. Las excepciones se pueden detectar usando eval{} . Consulte perlfunc y perlvar para obtener más detalles.

trans-unit.source: Fatal provides a way to conveniently replace functions which normally return a false value when they fail with equivalents which raise exceptions if they are not successful. This lets you use these functions without having to test their return values explicitly on each call. Exceptions can be caught using eval{}. See perlfunc and perlvar for details.

FdGetOsFHandle simply calls _get_osfhandle(). It was renamed to better fit in with the rest the function names of this module, in particular to distinguish it from GetOsFHandle. It takes an integer file descriptor [as from Perl's fileno] and returns the Win32 native file handle associated with that file descriptor or INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE if $ivFd is not an open file descriptor.

trans-unit.source: File::Fetch is relatively smart about things. When trying to write a file to disk, it removes the query parameters (see the output_file method for details) from the file name before creating it. In most cases this suffices.
trans-unit.target: File::Fetch es relativamente inteligente sobre las cosas. Al intentar escribir un archivo en el disco, se eliminan los query parameters (consulte el método output_file para obtener más detalles) del nombre del archivo antes de crearlo. En la mayoría de los casos, esto es suficiente.

trans-unit.source: File::Glob::glob() was deprecated in Perl 5.8. A deprecation message was issued from Perl 5.26 onwards, and the function has now disappeared in Perl 5.30.

File::Glob has a function called glob, which just calls bsd_glob.
File::Glob has a function called glob, which just calls bsd_glob. However, its prototype is different from the prototype of CORE::glob, and hence, File::Glob::glob should not be used.

File::GlobMapper has been kept simple deliberately, so it isn't intended to solve all filename mapping operations. Under the hood File::Glob (or for older versions of Perl, File::BSDGlob ) is used to match the files, so you will never have the flexibility of full Perl regular expression.
trans-unit.target: File::GlobMapper se ha mantenido simple deliberadamente, por lo que no está destinado a resolver todas las operaciones de asignación de nombres de archivos. Bajo el capó File::Glob (o para versiones anteriores de Perl, File::BSDGlob ) se utiliza para que coincida con los archivos, por lo que nunca tendrá la flexibilidad de la plena expresión regular Perl.

trans-unit.source: File::GlobMapper has been kept simple deliberately, so it isn't intended to solve all filename mapping operations. Under the hood File::Glob (or for older versions of Perl, File::BSDGlob) is used to match the files, so you will never have the flexibility of full Perl regular expression.

trans-unit.source: File::Spec is available in the standard distribution as of version 5.004_05. File::Spec::Functions is only in File::Spec 0.7 and later, and some versions of Perl come with version 0.6. If File::Spec is not updated to 0.7 or later, you must use the object-oriented interface from File::Spec (or upgrade File::Spec ).
trans-unit.target: File::Spec está disponible en la distribución estándar a partir de la versión 5.004_05. File::Spec::Functions está solo en File::Spec 0.7 y posteriores, y algunas versiones de Perl vienen con la versión 0.6. Si File::Spec no se actualiza a 0.7 o posterior, debe usar la interfaz orientada a objetos de File::Spec (o actualizar File::Spec ).

trans-unit.source: File::Temp can be used to create and open temporary files in a safe way. There is both a function interface and an object-oriented interface. The File::Temp constructor or the tempfile() function can be used to return the name and the open filehandle of a temporary file. The tempdir() function can be used to create a temporary directory.
trans-unit.target: File::Temp se puede utilizar para crear y abrir archivos temporales de forma segura. Hay una interfaz de función y una interfaz orientada a objetos. El constructor File :: Temp o la función tempfile () se pueden usar para devolver el nombre y el identificador de archivo abierto de un archivo temporal. La función tempdir () se puede utilizar para crear un directorio temporal.

FileHandle::fdopen is like open except that its first parameter is not a filename but rather a file handle name, a FileHandle object, or a file descriptor number.
trans-unit.target: FileHandle::fdopen es como open , excepto que su primer parámetro no es un nombre de archivo, sino un nombre de identificador de archivo, un objeto FileHandle o un número de descriptor de archivo.

trans-unit.source: FileHandle::fdopen is like open except that its first parameter is not a filename but rather a file handle name, a FileHandle object, or a file descriptor number.

FileHandle::new creates a FileHandle , which is a reference to a newly created symbol (see the Symbol package). If it receives any parameters, they are passed to FileHandle::open ; if the open fails, the FileHandle object is destroyed. Otherwise, it is returned to the caller.
trans-unit.target: FileHandle::new crea un FileHandle , que es una referencia a un símbolo recién creado (consulte el paquete de Symbol ). Si recibe algún parámetro, se pasa a FileHandle::open ; si la apertura falla, el objeto FileHandle se destruye. De lo contrario, se devuelve a la persona que llama.

trans-unit.source: FileHandle::new creates a FileHandle, which is a reference to a newly created symbol (see the Symbol package). If it receives any parameters, they are passed to FileHandle::open; if the open fails, the FileHandle object is destroyed. Otherwise, it is returned to the caller.

FileHandle::new_from_fd creates a FileHandle like new does. It requires two parameters, which are passed to FileHandle::fdopen ; if the fdopen fails, the FileHandle object is destroyed. Otherwise, it is returned to the caller.
trans-unit.target: FileHandle::new_from_fd crea un FileHandle como lo hace new . Requiere dos parámetros, que se pasan a FileHandle::fdopen ; si falla el fdopen, el objeto FileHandle se destruye. De lo contrario, se devuelve a la persona que llama.

trans-unit.source: FileHandle::new_from_fd creates a FileHandle like new does. It requires two parameters, which are passed to FileHandle::fdopen; if the fdopen fails, the FileHandle object is destroyed. Otherwise, it is returned to the caller.

FileHandle::open accepts one parameter or two. With one parameter, it is just a front end for the built-in open function. With two parameters, the first parameter is a filename that may include whitespace or other special characters, and the second parameter is the open mode, optionally followed by a file permission value.
trans-unit.target: FileHandle::open acepta uno o dos parámetros. Con un parámetro, es solo una interfaz para la función open incorporada. Con dos parámetros, el primer parámetro es un nombre de archivo que puede incluir espacios en blanco u otros caracteres especiales, y el segundo parámetro es el modo abierto, seguido opcionalmente por un valor de permiso de archivo.

trans-unit.source: FileHandle::open accepts one parameter or two. With one parameter, it is just a front end for the built-in open function. With two parameters, the first parameter is a filename that may include whitespace or other special characters, and the second parameter is the open mode, optionally followed by a file permission value.
