IO::Dir also provides an interface to reading directories via a tied hash. The tied hash extends the interface beyond just the directory reading routines by the use of lstat, from the File::stat package, unlink, rmdir and utime.
trans-unit.target: IO::Dir también proporciona una interfaz para leer directorios mediante un hash vinculado. El hash vinculado extiende la interfaz más allá de las rutinas de lectura de directorios mediante el uso de lstat , del paquete File::stat , unlink , rmdir y utime .

trans-unit.source: IO::Dir also provides an interface to reading directories via a tied hash. The tied hash extends the interface beyond just the directory reading routines by the use of lstat, from the File::stat package, unlink, rmdir and utime.
IO::File inherits from IO::Handle and IO::Seekable . It extends these classes with methods that are specific to file handles.
trans-unit.target: IO::File hereda de IO::Handle y IO::Seekable . Extiende estas clases con métodos que son específicos de los identificadores de archivos.

trans-unit.source: IO::File inherits from IO::Handle and IO::Seekable. It extends these classes with methods that are specific to file handles.

IO::Handle is the base class for all other IO handle classes. It is not intended that objects of IO::Handle would be created directly, but instead IO::Handle is inherited from by several other classes in the IO hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: IO::Handle es la clase base para todas las demás clases de handle de IO. No se pretende que los objetos de IO::Handle se creen directamente, sino que IO::Handle es heredado por varias otras clases en la jerarquía de IO.

trans-unit.source: IO::Pipe provides an interface to creating pipes between processes.
trans-unit.target: IO::Pipe proporciona una interfaz para crear conductos entre procesos.

trans-unit.source: IO::Poll is a simple interface to the system level poll routine.
trans-unit.target: IO::Poll es una interfaz simple para la rutina de sondeo a nivel del sistema.

trans-unit.source: IO::Seekable does not have a constructor of its own as it is intended to be inherited by other IO::Handle based objects. It provides methods which allow seeking of the file descriptors.
trans-unit.target: IO::Seekable no tiene un constructor propio, ya que está destinado a ser heredado por otros objetos basados en IO::Handle . Proporciona métodos que permiten la búsqueda de descriptores de archivos.

IO::Socket::IP implements both the Blocking and Timeout parameters, but it implements the interaction of both in a different way.

IO::Socket is a base class that really only defines methods for those operations which are common to all types of sockets. Operations which are specific to a particular socket domain have methods defined in subclasses of IO::Socket. See IO::Socket::INET, IO::Socket::UNIX, and IO::Socket::IP for examples of such a subclass.

IO::Socket only defines methods for those operations which are common to all types of socket. Operations which are specified to a socket in a particular domain have methods defined in sub classes of IO::Socket
trans-unit.target: IO::Socket solo define métodos para aquellas operaciones que son comunes a todos los tipos de socket. Las operaciones que se especifican en un socket en un dominio particular tienen métodos definidos en subclases de IO::Socket

LDLOADLIBS is an environment variable used by the linker to link /ext modules to glibc. Currently, that environment variable is not getting populated by a combination of Config entries and ExtUtil::MakeMaker. While there may be a bug somewhere in Perl's configuration or ExtUtil::MakeMaker causing the problem, the most likely cause is an incomplete understanding of Sun Studio by this author. Further investigation is needed to get this working better.

LDLOADLIBS is an environment variable used by the linker to link modules /ext modules to glibc. Currently, that environment variable is not getting populated by a combination of Config entries and ExtUtil::MakeMaker . While there may be a bug somewhere in Perl's configuration or ExtUtil::MakeMaker causing the problem, the most likely cause is an incomplete understanding of Sun Studio by this author. Further investigation is needed to get this working better.
trans-unit.target: LDLOADLIBS es una variable de entorno utilizada por el enlazador para vincular módulos /ext módulos ext a glibc. Actualmente, esa variable de entorno no se completa con una combinación de entradas de Config y ExtUtil::MakeMaker . Si bien puede haber un error en alguna parte de la configuración de Perl o ExtUtil::MakeMaker causando el problema, la causa más probable es una comprensión incompleta de Sun Studio por parte de este autor. Se necesita más investigación para que esto funcione mejor.

trans-unit.source: List::Util::XS can be used as a dependency to ensure List::Util was installed using a C compiler and that the XS version is installed.
trans-unit.target: List::Util::XS se puede usar como una dependencia para asegurar que List :: Util se instaló usando un compilador de C y que la versión XS está instalada.

trans-unit.source: List::Util contains a selection of subroutines that people have expressed would be nice to have in the perl core, but the usage would not really be high enough to warrant the use of a keyword, and the size so small such that being individual extensions would be wasteful.
trans-unit.target: List::Util contiene una selección de subrutinas que la gente ha expresado que sería bueno tener en el núcleo de perl, pero el uso no sería lo suficientemente alto como para justificar el uso de una palabra clave, y el tamaño es tan pequeño como para ser extensiones individuales. sería un desperdicio.

trans-unit.source: MEMORY means that return values from the function will be cached in an ordinary Perl hash variable. The hash variable will not persist after the program exits. This is the default.
trans-unit.target: MEMORY significa que los valores de retorno de la función se almacenarán en caché en una variable hash de Perl ordinaria. La variable hash no persistirá después de que se cierre el programa. Este es el predeterminado.

trans-unit.source: MERGE normally means that the memoized function does not distinguish between list and sclar context, and that return values in both contexts should be stored together. Both LIST_CACHE => MERGE and SCALAR_CACHE => MERGE mean the same thing.
trans-unit.target: MERGE normalmente significa que la función memorizada no distingue entre el contexto list y sclar, y que los valores de retorno en ambos contextos deben almacenarse juntos. Tanto LIST_CACHE => MERGE como SCALAR_CACHE => MERGE significan lo mismo.

trans-unit.source: MESSAGE-SPEC is either a single message-id, a single message number, or a reference to a list of two message numbers.
trans-unit.target: MESSAGE-SPEC es un ID de mensaje único, un número de mensaje único o una referencia a una lista de dos números de mensaje.

trans-unit.source: MESSAGE can be either an array of lines or a reference to an array and must be encoded by the caller to octets of whatever encoding is required, e.g. by using the Encode module's encode() function.
MESSAGE can be either an array of lines or a reference to an array.

MSGNUM is a numeric id of an article in the current newsgroup, and will change the current article pointer. MSGID is the message id of an article as shown in that article's header. It is anticipated that the client will obtain the MSGID from a list provided by the newnews command, from references contained within another article, or from the message-id provided in the response to some other commands.
trans-unit.target: MSGNUM es una identificación numérica de un artículo en el grupo de noticias actual y cambiará el puntero del artículo actual. MSGID es la identificación del mensaje de un artículo como se muestra en el encabezado de ese artículo. Se prevé que el cliente obtendrá el MSGID de una lista proporcionada por el comando newnews , de las referencias contenidas en otro artículo o del ID del mensaje proporcionado en la respuesta a algunos otros comandos.

trans-unit.source: Moo does not implement most of Moose 's introspection API, so it's often faster when loading your modules. Additionally, none of its dependencies require XS, so it can be installed on machines without a compiler.
trans-unit.target: Moo no implementa la mayor parte de la API de introspección de Moose , por lo que a menudo es más rápido al cargar sus módulos. Además, ninguna de sus dependencias requiere XS, por lo que se puede instalar en máquinas sin un compilador.

trans-unit.source: Moo does not implement most of Moose's introspection API, so it's often faster when loading your modules. Additionally, none of its dependencies require XS, so it can be installed on machines without a compiler.

Moose also has several dependencies on other modules. Most of these are small stand-alone modules, a number of which have been spun off from Moose . Moose itself, and some of its dependencies, require a compiler. If you need to install your software on a system without a compiler, or if having
trans-unit.target: Moose también tiene varias dependencias en otros módulos. La mayoría de estos son pequeños módulos independientes, algunos de los cuales se han derivado de Moose . trans-unit.source: Moose describes itself using its own introspection API. Besides being a cool trick, this means that you can extend Moose using Moose itself.
trans-unit.target: Moose se describe a sí mismo utilizando su propia API de introspección. Además de ser un truco genial, esto significa que puedes extender Moose usando Moose mismo.

trans-unit.source: Moose is a very powerful tool, and we can't cover all of its features here. We encourage you to learn more by reading the Moose documentation, starting with Moose::Manual.
trans-unit.target: Moose es una herramienta muy poderosa y no podemos cubrir todas sus características aquí. Le animamos a aprender más leyendo la documentación de Moose , comenzando con Moose :: Manual .

trans-unit.source: Moose is a very powerful tool, and we can't cover all of its features here. We encourage you to learn more by reading the Moose documentation, starting with Moose::Manual.

Moose is the maximal option. It has a lot of features, a big ecosystem, and a thriving user base. We also covered Moo briefly. Moo is Moose lite, and a reasonable alternative when Moose doesn't work for your application.
trans-unit.target: Moose es la opción máxima. Tiene muchas características, un gran ecosistema y una base de usuarios próspera. También cubrimos Moo brevemente. Moo es Moose lite y una alternativa razonable cuando Moose no funciona para su aplicación.

trans-unit.source: Moose is the maximal option. It has a lot of features, a big ecosystem, and a thriving user base. We also covered Moo briefly. Moo is Moose lite, and a reasonable alternative when Moose doesn't work for your application.
Moose lets you define roles the same way you define classes:

trans-unit.source: Moose provides a complete, modern OO system. Its biggest influence is the Common Lisp Object System, but it also borrows ideas from Smalltalk and several other languages. Moose was created by Stevan Little, and draws heavily from his work on the Perl 6 OO design.
trans-unit.target: Moose proporciona un sistema OO completo y moderno. Su mayor influencia es el Common Lisp Object System, pero también toma prestadas ideas de Smalltalk y varios otros lenguajes. Moose fue creado por Stevan Little y se basa en gran medida en su trabajo en el diseño de Perl 6 OO.

trans-unit.source: Moose provides a complete, modern OO system. Its biggest influence is the Common Lisp Object System, but it also borrows ideas from Smalltalk and several other languages. Moose was created by Stevan Little, and draws heavily from his work on the Raku OO design.

trans-unit.source: NDBM_File establishes a connection between a Perl hash variable and a file in NDBM_File format;. You can manipulate the data in the file just as if it were in a Perl hash, but when your program exits, the data will remain in the file, to be used the next time your program runs.
trans-unit.target: NDBM_File establece una conexión entre una variable hash de Perl y un archivo en formato NDBM_File ;. Puede manipular los datos en el archivo como si estuviera en un hash de Perl, pero cuando su programa sale, los datos permanecerán en el archivo, para ser utilizados la próxima vez que se ejecute su programa.

NUL characters will sort the same as the lowest collating control character does, or to "\001" in the unlikely event that there are no control characters at all in the locale. In cases where the strings don't contain this non-NUL control, the results will be correct, and in many locales, this control, whatever it might be, will rarely be encountered. But there are cases where a NUL should sort before this control, but doesn't. If two strings do collate identically, the one containing the NUL will sort to earlier. Prior to 5.26, there were more bugs.

trans-unit.source: Net::Cmd exports six subroutines, five of these, CMD_INFO , CMD_OK , CMD_MORE , CMD_REJECT and CMD_ERROR , correspond to possible results of response and status . The sixth is CMD_PENDING .
trans-unit.target: Net::Cmd exporta seis subrutinas, cinco de estas, CMD_INFO , CMD_OK , CMD_MORE , CMD_REJECT y CMD_ERROR , corresponden a posibles resultados de response y status . El sexto es CMD_PENDING .

trans-unit.source: Net::Cmd exports six subroutines, five of these, CMD_INFO, CMD_OK, CMD_MORE, CMD_REJECT and CMD_ERROR, correspond to possible results of response and status. The sixth is CMD_PENDING.
Net::Cmd is a collection of methods that can be inherited by a sub class of IO::Handle . These methods implement the functionality required for a command based protocol, for example FTP and SMTP.
trans-unit.target: Net::Cmd es una colección de métodos que puede heredar una subclase de IO::Handle . Estos métodos implementan la funcionalidad requerida para un protocolo basado en comandos, por ejemplo, FTP y SMTP.

trans-unit.source: Net::Cmd is a collection of methods that can be inherited by a sub-class of IO::Socket::INET. These methods implement the functionality required for a command based protocol, for example FTP and SMTP.

Net::Config defines the following methods. They are methods as they are invoked as class methods. This is because Net::Config inherits from Net::LocalCfg so you can override these methods if you want.
trans-unit.target: Net::Config define los siguientes métodos. Son métodos ya que se invocan como métodos de clase. Esto se debe a que Net::Config hereda de Net::LocalCfg por lo que puede anular estos métodos si lo desea.

trans-unit.source: Net::Config holds configuration data for the modules in the libnet distribution. During installation you will be asked for these values.
trans-unit.target: Net::Config contiene datos de configuración para los módulos en la distribución libnet. Durante la instalación se le pedirán estos valores.

trans-unit.source: Net::FTP inherits from Net::Cmd so methods defined in Net::Cmd may be used to send commands to the remote FTP server in addition to the methods documented here.
trans-unit.target: Net::FTP hereda de Net::Cmd por lo que los métodos definidos en Net::Cmd pueden usarse para enviar comandos al servidor FTP remoto además de los métodos documentados aquí.

trans-unit.source: Net::FTP is a class implementing a simple FTP client in Perl as described in RFC959. It provides wrappers for a subset of the RFC959 commands.
trans-unit.target: Net::FTP es una clase que implementa un cliente FTP simple en Perl como se describe en RFC959. Proporciona envoltorios para un subconjunto de los comandos RFC959.

trans-unit.source: Net::FTP is a class implementing a simple FTP client in Perl as described in RFC959. It provides wrappers for the commonly used subset of the RFC959 commands. If IO::Socket::IP or IO::Socket::INET6 is installed it also provides support for IPv6 as defined in RFC2428. And with IO::Socket::SSL installed it provides support for implicit FTPS and explicit FTPS as defined in RFC4217.
Net::NNTP inherits from Net::Cmd so methods defined in Net::Cmd may be used to send commands to the remote NNTP server in addition to the methods documented here.
trans-unit.target: Net::NNTP hereda de Net::Cmd por lo que los métodos definidos en Net::Cmd pueden usarse para enviar comandos al servidor NNTP remoto además de los métodos documentados aquí.

trans-unit.source: Net::NNTP is a class implementing a simple NNTP client in Perl as described in RFC977 and RFC4642.
trans-unit.target: Net::NNTP es una clase que implementa un cliente NNTP simple en Perl como se describe en RFC977 y RFC4642.

trans-unit.source: Net::NNTP is a class implementing a simple NNTP client in Perl as described in RFC977 and RFC4642. With IO::Socket::SSL installed it also provides support for implicit and explicit TLS encryption, i.e. NNTPS or NNTP+STARTTLS.

Net::Netrc also implements security checks just like the ftp program, these checks are, first that the .netrc file must be owned by the user and second the ownership permissions should be such that only the owner has read and write access. If these conditions are not met then a warning is output and the .netrc file is not read.
trans-unit.target: Net::Netrc también implementa controles de seguridad al igual que el programa ftp, estos controles son, primero que el archivo .netrc debe ser propiedad del usuario y segundo, los permisos de propiedad deben ser tales que solo el propietario tenga acceso de lectura y escritura. Si no se cumplen estas condiciones, se emite una advertencia y no se lee el archivo .netrc.

trans-unit.source: Net::Netrc is a class implementing a simple interface to the .netrc file used as by the ftp program.
trans-unit.target: Net::Netrc es una clase que implementa una interfaz simple para el archivo .netrc que usa el programa ftp.

OsFHandleOpen eventually calls the Win32-specific C routine _open_osfhandle() or Perl's "improved" version called win32_open_osfhandle(). We use a local temporary, err_tmp, since ERRSV is a macro that calls a function, and SvTRUE(ERRSV) would end up calling that function multiple times.

PL_modglobal is a general purpose, interpreter global HV for use by extensions that need to keep information on a per-interpreter basis. In a pinch, it can also be used as a symbol table for extensions to share data among each other. It is a good idea to use keys prefixed by the package name of the extension that owns the data.
trans-unit.target: PL_modglobal es un intérprete global HV de propósito general para ser utilizado por extensiones que necesitan mantener información por intérprete. En caso de necesidad, también se puede utilizar como una tabla de símbolos para que las extensiones compartan datos entre sí. Es una buena idea utilizar claves con el prefijo del nombre del paquete de la extensión que posee los datos.

POPn takes the SV from the top of the stack and obtains its NV either directly (if SvNOK is set) or by calling the sv_2nv function. TOPs takes the next SV from the top of the stack - yes, POPn uses TOPs - but doesn't remove it. We then use SvNV to get the NV from leftsv in the same way as before - yes, POPn uses SvNV .
trans-unit.target: POPn toma el SV de la parte superior de la pila y obtiene su NV directamente (si se establece SvNOK ) o llamando a la función sv_2nv . TOPs toma el siguiente SV de la parte superior de la pila (sí, POPn usa TOPs ) pero no lo elimina. Luego usamos SvNV para obtener el NV de leftsv de la misma manera que antes; sí, POPn usa SvNV .

SAVEFREEOP is slightly problematic under this scheme. Sometimes it can cause an op to be freed after its CV. If the CV has forcibly freed the ops on its slab and the slab itself, then we will be fiddling with a freed slab. Making SAVEFREEOP a no-op doesn't help, as sometimes an op can be savefreed when there is no compilation error, so the op would never be freed. It holds a reference count on the slab, so the whole slab would leak. So SAVEFREEOP now sets a special flag on the op (->op_savefree). The forced freeing of ops after a compilation error won't free any ops thus marked.

SVt_PVGV represents a typeglob. If !SvFAKE(sv), then it is a real, incoercible typeglob. If SvFAKE(sv), then it is a scalar to which a typeglob has been assigned. Assigning to it again will stop it from being a typeglob. SVt_PVLV represents a scalar that delegates to another scalar behind the scenes. It is used, e.g., for the return value of substr and for tied hash and array elements. It can hold any scalar value, including a typeglob. SVt_REGEXP is for regular expressions. SVt_INVLIST is for Perl core internal use only.
SVt_PVIO is for I/O objects, SVt_PVFM for formats, SVt_PVCV for subroutines, SVt_PVHV for hashes and SVt_PVAV for arrays.

SVt_PVMG represents a "normal" scalar (not a typeglob, regular expression, or delegate). Since most scalars do not need all the internal fields of a PVMG, we save memory by allocating smaller structs when possible. All the other types are just simpler forms of SVt_PVMG, with fewer internal fields. SVt_NULL can only hold undef. SVt_IV can hold undef, an integer, or a reference. (SVt_RV is an alias for SVt_IV, which exists for backward compatibility.) SVt_NV can hold any of those or a double. SVt_PV can only hold undef or a string. SVt_PVIV is a superset of SVt_PV and SVt_IV. SVt_PVNV is similar. SVt_PVMG can hold anything SVt_PVNV can hold, but it can, but does not have to, be blessed or magical.

trans-unit.source: Scalar::Util contains a selection of subroutines that people have expressed would be nice to have in the perl core, but the usage would not really be high enough to warrant the use of a keyword, and the size so small such that being individual extensions would be wasteful.

trans-unit.source: Scalar::Util contains a selection of subroutines that people have expressed would be nice to have in the perl core, but the usage would not really be high enough to warrant the use of a keyword, and the size would be so small that being individual extensions would be wasteful.

Scalar::Util contains both perl and C implementations of many of its functions so that those without access to a C compiler may still use it. However some of the functions are only available when a C compiler was available to compile the XS version of the extension.
trans-unit.target: Scalar::Util contiene implementaciones de perl y C de muchas de sus funciones, de modo que aquellos que no tienen acceso a un compilador de C aún pueden usarlo. Sin embargo, algunas de las funciones solo están disponibles cuando un compilador de C estaba disponible para compilar la versión XS de la extensión.

trans-unit.source: Script_Extensions is thus an improved Script , in which there are fewer characters in the Common script, and correspondingly more in other scripts. It is new in Unicode version 6.0, and its data are likely to change significantly in later releases, as things get sorted out. New code should probably be using Script_Extensions and not plain Script .
trans-unit.target: Script_Extensions es, por tanto, un Script mejorado , en el que hay menos caracteres en el script Common y, en consecuencia, más en otros scripts. Es nuevo en la versión 6.0 de Unicode, y es probable que sus datos cambien significativamente en versiones posteriores, a medida que se resuelvan las cosas. El nuevo código probablemente debería usar Script_Extensions y no un Script simple .

trans-unit.source: Script_Extensions is thus an improved Script, in which there are fewer characters in the Common script, and correspondingly more in other scripts. It is new in Unicode version 6.0, and its data are likely to change significantly in later releases, as things get sorted out. New code should probably be using Script_Extensions and not plain Script. If you compile perl with a Unicode release that doesn't have Script_Extensions, the single form Perl extensions will instead refer to the plain Script property. If you compile with a version of Unicode that doesn't have the Script property, these extensions will not be defined at all.

Storable::drop_utf8 is a blunt tool. There is no facility either to return all strings as utf8 sequences, or to attempt to convert utf8 data back to 8 bit and croak() if the conversion fails.
trans-unit.target: Storable::drop_utf8 es una herramienta contundente. No hay ninguna posibilidad para devolver todas las cadenas como secuencias utf8, ni para intentar convertir los datos utf8 a 8 bits y croak() si la conversión falla.

trans-unit.source: Storable isn't a tied hash class at all. You can use it to store a hash to disk and retrieve it again, but you can't modify the hash while it's on the disk. So if you want to store your cache table in a Storable database, use Memoize::Storable , which puts a hashlike front-end onto Storable . The hash table is actually kept in memory, and is loaded from your Storable file at the time you memoize the function, and stored back at the time you unmemoize the function (or when your program exits):
trans-unit.target: Storable no es una clase de hash empatada en absoluto. Puede usarlo para almacenar un hash en el disco y recuperarlo nuevamente, pero no puede modificar el hash mientras está en el disco. Así que si usted desea almacenar la tabla de caché en un Storable base de datos, utilice Memoize::Storable , que pone un front-end hashlike en Storable . La tabla hash es en realidad mantiene en la memoria, y se carga desde su Storable archivo en el momento de memoize la función, y vuelve a almacenar en el momento de unmemoize la función (o cuando sus salidas del programa):

trans-unit.source: Storable isn't a tied hash class at all. You can use it to store a hash to disk and retrieve it again, but you can't modify the hash while it's on the disk. So if you want to store your cache table in a Storable database, use Memoize::Storable, which puts a hashlike front-end onto Storable. The hash table is actually kept in memory, and is loaded from your Storable file at the time you memoize the function, and stored back at the time you unmemoize the function (or when your program exits):

Symbol::delete_package is a bit too powerful. It undefines every symbol that lives in the specified package. Since perl, for performance reasons, does not perform a symbol table lookup each time a function is called or a global variable is accessed, some code that has already been loaded and that makes use of symbols in package Foo may stop working after you delete Foo , even if you reload the Foo module afterwards.
trans-unit.target: Symbol::delete_package es demasiado poderoso. Define cada símbolo que vive en el paquete especificado. Desde el Perl, por razones de rendimiento, no se realizará una mesa de búsqueda de símbolos cada vez que una función se llama o se accede a una variable global, un código que ya ha sido cargado y que hace uso de símbolos en el paquete de Foo puede dejar de funcionar después de eliminar Foo , incluso si vuelve a cargar el módulo Foo después.

trans-unit.source: Symbol::delete_package is a bit too powerful. It undefines every symbol that lives in the specified package. Since perl, for performance reasons, does not perform a symbol table lookup each time a function is called or a global variable is accessed, some code that has already been loaded and that makes use of symbols in package Foo may stop working after you delete Foo, even if you reload the Foo module afterwards.
Symbol::delete_package wipes out a whole package namespace. Note this routine is not exported by default--you may want to import it explicitly.
trans-unit.target: Symbol::delete_package borra todo el espacio de nombres de un paquete. Tenga en cuenta que esta rutina no se exporta de forma predeterminada; es posible que desee importarla explícitamente.

trans-unit.source: Symbol::geniosym creates an anonymous IO handle. This can be assigned into an existing glob without affecting the non-IO portions of the glob.
trans-unit.target: Symbol::geniosym crea un identificador IO anónimo. Esto se puede asignar a un glob existente sin afectar las porciones que no son IO del glob.

trans-unit.source: Symbol::gensym creates an anonymous glob and returns a reference to it. Such a glob reference can be used as a file or directory handle.
trans-unit.target: Symbol::gensym crea un glob anónimo y devuelve una referencia a él. Una referencia global de este tipo se puede utilizar como identificador de archivo o directorio.

trans-unit.source: Symbol::qualify turns unqualified symbol names into qualified variable names (e.g. "myvar" -> "MyPackage::myvar"). If it is given a second parameter, qualify uses it as the default package; otherwise, it uses the package of its caller. Regardless, global variable names (e.g. "STDOUT", "ENV", "SIG") are always qualified with "main::".
trans-unit.target: Symbol::qualify convierte nombres de símbolos no calificados en nombres de variables calificados (por ejemplo, "myvar" -> "MyPackage :: myvar"). Si se le da un segundo parámetro, qualify lo usa como el paquete predeterminado; de lo contrario, utiliza el paquete de su llamador. Independientemente, los nombres de variables globales (por ejemplo, "STDOUT", "ENV", "SIG") siempre se califican con "main ::".

trans-unit.source: Symbol::qualify_to_ref is just like Symbol::qualify except that it returns a glob ref rather than a symbol name, so you can use the result even if use strict 'refs' is in effect.
trans-unit.target: Symbol::qualify_to_ref es como Symbol::qualify excepto que devuelve una referencia pegote en lugar de un nombre de símbolo, por lo que puede utilizar el resultado, aunque use strict 'refs' está en vigor.

trans-unit.source: Symbol::qualify_to_ref is just like Symbol::qualify except that it returns a glob ref rather than a symbol name, so you can use the result even if use strict 'refs' is in effect.

trans-unit.source: Sys::Syslog is an interface to the UNIX syslog(3) program. Call syslog() with a string priority and a list of printf() args just like syslog(3) .
trans-unit.target: Sys::Syslog es una interfaz para el programa syslog(3) UNIX . Llame a syslog() con una prioridad de cadena y una lista de printf() de printf () como syslog(3) .

trans-unit.source: Sys::Syslog is an interface to the UNIX syslog(3) program. Call syslog() with a string priority and a list of printf() args just like syslog(3).

Sys::Syslog version v0.07 and older passed the $message as the formatting string to sprintf() even when no formatting arguments were provided. If the code calling syslog() might execute with older versions of this module, make sure to call the function as syslog($priority, "%s", $message) instead of syslog($priority, $message) . This protects against hostile formatting sequences that might show up if $message contains tainted data.
trans-unit.target: Sys::Syslog versión v0.07 y anteriores pasó el $message como cadena de formato a sprintf() incluso cuando no se proporcionaron argumentos de formato. Si el código que llama a syslog() puede ejecutarse con versiones anteriores de este módulo, asegúrese de llamar a la función como syslog($priority, "%s", $message) lugar de syslog($priority, $message) . Esto protege contra secuencias de formato hostiles que pueden aparecer si $ message contiene datos contaminados.

trans-unit.source: Sys::Syslog version v0.07 and older passed the $message as the formatting string to sprintf() even when no formatting arguments were provided. If the code calling syslog() might execute with older versions of this module, make sure to call the function as syslog($priority, "%s", $message) instead of syslog($priority, $message). This protects against hostile formatting sequences that might show up if $message contains tainted data.

trans-unit.source: Text::Wrap::fill() is a simple multi-paragraph formatter. It formats each paragraph separately and then joins them together when it's done. It will destroy any whitespace in the original text. It breaks text into paragraphs by looking for whitespace after a newline. In other respects, it acts like wrap().
trans-unit.target: Text::Wrap::fill() es un formateador simple de varios párrafos. Formatea cada párrafo por separado y luego los une cuando está listo. Destruirá cualquier espacio en blanco en el texto original. Divide el texto en párrafos buscando espacios en blanco después de una nueva línea. En otros aspectos, actúa como wrap ().

trans-unit.source: Text::Wrap::wrap() has a number of variables that control its behavior. Because other modules might be using Text::Wrap::wrap() it is suggested that you leave these variables alone! If you can't do that, then use local($Text::Wrap::VARIABLE) = YOURVALUE when you change the values so that the original value is restored. This local() trick will not work if you import the variable into your own namespace.
trans-unit.target: Text::Wrap::wrap() tiene una serie de variables que controlan su comportamiento. Debido a que otros módulos podrían estar usando Text::Wrap::wrap() , se sugiere que deje estas variables en paz. Si no puede hacer eso, use local($Text::Wrap::VARIABLE) = YOURVALUE cuando cambie los valores para que se restaure el valor original. Este truco local() no funcionará si importa la variable a su propio espacio de nombres.

trans-unit.source: Text::Wrap::wrap() has a number of variables that control its behavior. Because other modules might be using Text::Wrap::wrap() it is suggested that you leave these variables alone! If you can't do that, then use local($Text::Wrap::VARIABLE) = YOURVALUE when you change the values so that the original value is restored. This local() trick will not work if you import the variable into your own namespace.

Text::Wrap::wrap() is a very simple paragraph formatter. It formats a single paragraph at a time by breaking lines at word boundaries. Indentation is controlled for the first line ($initial_tab ) and all subsequent lines ($subsequent_tab ) independently. Please note: $initial_tab and $subsequent_tab are the literal strings that will be used: it is unlikely you would want to pass in a number.
trans-unit.target: Text::Wrap::wrap() es un formateador de párrafos muy simple. Formatea un solo párrafo a la vez dividiendo las líneas en los límites de las palabras. La sangría se controla para la primera línea ( $initial_tab ) y todas las líneas siguientes ( $subsequent_tab ) de forma independiente. Tenga en cuenta: $initial_tab y $subsequent_tab son las cadenas literales que se utilizarán: es poco probable que desee pasar un número.

trans-unit.source: Text::Wrap::wrap() is a very simple paragraph formatter. It formats a single paragraph at a time by breaking lines at word boundaries. Indentation is controlled for the first line ($initial_tab) and all subsequent lines ($subsequent_tab) independently. Please note: $initial_tab and $subsequent_tab are the literal strings that will be used: it is unlikely you would want to pass in a number.

Text::Wrap::wrap() starts its work by expanding all the tabs in its input into spaces. The last thing it does it to turn spaces back into tabs. If you do not want tabs in your results, set $Text::Wrap::unexpand to a false value. Likewise if you do not want to use 8-character tabstops, set $Text::Wrap::tabstop to the number of characters you do want for your tabstops.
trans-unit.target: Text::Wrap::wrap() comienza su trabajo expandiendo todas las pestañas en su entrada en espacios. Lo último que hace es volver a convertir espacios en pestañas. Si no desea pestañas en sus resultados, establezca $Text::Wrap::unexpand en un valor falso. Del mismo modo, si no desea utilizar tabstops de 8 caracteres, configure $Text::Wrap::tabstop en el número de caracteres que desee para sus tabuladores.

trans-unit.source: Tie::File represents a regular text file as a Perl array. Each element in the array corresponds to a record in the file. The first line of the file is element 0 of the array; the second line is element 1, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Tie::File representa un archivo de texto normal como una matriz de Perl. Cada elemento de la matriz corresponde a un registro en el archivo. La primera línea del archivo es el elemento 0 de la matriz; la segunda línea es el elemento 1, y así sucesivamente.
